comments.text:
You shouldn't be concerned with the numbers on the scale. muscles weigh 
more than fat and so on so you really can't know what it is that is 
weighing. Just like you can't know if 100 kcal is good or bad, because what 
matters is what the calories consist of. 
For example, 100 kcal of cow milk is much more unhealthy than 100 kcal of 
soy milk. 100 kcal or beef is much more unhealthy than 100 kcal of soy 
beans. 
My suggestion is that you make eating a happy and joyful action rather than 
a guilty one. See food as FUEL, because that's what it is. The food fuels 
your body so it's best to eat food that suits your body so that you feel on 
top. 

I eat a lot of garbage, chips, pancakes almost every day with whipped soy 
cream etc. But it's all vegan, so it's much much healthier. Milk from 
animals is made for the baby to GROW, that's why people gain so much weight 
from it. milk is for babies. 

Your stomach can tell you when you should stop eating in two ways: either 
it has expanded so much that it knows you have had enough food, OR it has 
been filled with enough calories/''nutrition'' so that it tells you it 
doesn't need any more. you could have a half empty stomach with oils and 
other unhealthy things, or you can have a full stomach with spinach and 
fruit which will make you so happy and energetic.

I'm not saying you should focus on losing weight, I'm saying you should 
focus on what makes you feel the best physically, mentally and emotionally. 
I realized this is a lot of text so if you're interested you can please 
send me a message or we can just talk in the comments. good luck and happy 
birthday :)

No, it is bad what you are doing in every way. We are not supposed to 
starve ourselves. Even Gandhi only fasted for 21 days at a time before

you want to do! As for Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha), he was fasting to the 
point of almost dying and was in pain doing it. Sure, he reached 
enlightenment, but you may do it incorrectly and actually die. That's not 
the way to go! We're not supposed to suffer in pain from starvation just to 
reach some horrific goal weight!

Your body is wasting away with your routine...it's not weight loss in the 
correct sense. Unless you actually want to live and look like those in 
poverty who are literally dying for food, I think you're seriously going 
the wrong way about weight loss.

You are supposed to eat and poop! You want a laxative effect without buying 
random crap? *eat more fruit and vegetables* to cleanse your digestive 
system each day. You're still not getting all the necessary requirements 
your body needs and I'm no dietician! Where's your iron coming from? 
Where's your source of calcium too? Heck, I have a blood disorder which 
makes it impossible for me to absorb iron properly in any way. It could 
build up and kill me if I take iron supplements but you're intentionally 
skipping so much important nutrition that your body NEEDS.

Honestly, if you don't change your routine now, you are going to end up in 
hospital critically ill (and forced to eat until back at a healthy weight) 
or worse, you will die before getting there...and honestly, I don't want 
that to ever happen to you. For goodness sake, just eat!

Seriously, I'm sure you're taller and weigh less than me. I just came back 
from the doctors yesterday because I have put on 11kg in 10 months, but 
apparently my thyroid is still ok AND I'm perfectly healthy (apart from my 
low iron levels) and still well within my height's healthy weight range.

parents kept a close eye on my brother and I, but I still became anorexic 
at the age of 15 and was able to hide it by wearing oversized clothing all 
the time (I was a tomboy anyways). I was also a straight A student and in 
sports after school so they had no clue what was going on since I was also 
very independent and would make my own meals. 

You should really just shut the hell up as it is clear that you have no 
idea what you are talking about. And as far as "censorship", they are 
exercising their own rights to remove any comments they deem as 
"inappropriate".

comments.text:
I've had an eating disorder for around five years. I go through phases of 
each eating disorder. When it all began the last thing I was looking for 
was attention. In fact, I had no clue what I was doing. I believe I focused 
all my emotional problems on exercising, seeing I didn't want to talk about 
them. As they became worse, I became worse. I'm getting tired of people 
saying it's for attention, especially if they haven't faced it themselves. 
Sure, there are some people who brag about their problems on a daily. But 
then there's those people who want help desperately but don't know how to 
get it, or just don't have anyone to help them. But people saying it's 
merely for attention makes them scared to reach out.. Anorexia and Bulimia 
kill, there's no way around the health problems and mental problems they 
cause. They're both just as deadly having experienced both. They both slow 
down the metabolism, they cause you to become weak and dizzy, they do 
immense damage to the heart and organs. I've come close to death a few 
times because of it, yet I still didn't stop but for a while. Because when 
you're too far in you don't think about the consequences, although they're 
always in the back of your mind creeping up every once in a while just to 
freak you out.. It's nothing to do with others anymore, it's a battle with 
yourself. The thoughts never cease to exist, even in recovery.. Which leads 
to overwhelming fear and anxiety.. If not a relapse.. No one would go 
through this for attention.. Especially when the only "attention" it ever 
really brings is comments such as "You're dying." And if you don't, a life 
sentence of your mind..
comments.author: Jessica Clorine

comments.text:
+TheAllstar22 I agree. I've got an anorexic friend (now recovered) and 
because she heavily restricted for such a long time not only guttered her 
metabolic rate it also caused hypothyroidism.
It also aged her a lot.
If a normal person (or a wannarexic) would do a heavily restricted 
diet/starvation diet it's just like you say and they will yoyo diet their 
way up and it'll be a vicious cycle.
I don't really blame them though because there is such conflicting 
information about nutrition out there.
It seems as if scientists haven't made up their mind yet about what macro 
ratio's we should be eating.
There are even scientists who recommend prolonged fasting/starvation diets.
Maybe there is no "one diet to work for all" like a lot of people say, I 
think it's unlikely seeing as there are so many people with diabetes out 
there.
We definitely should not be giving those diabetics the same diet as people 
with normal pancreases. 
I've adopted a "if it works for you,  if you are getting all of your 
vitamins/minerals and if you are maintaining health then that's good but it 
might not work for the next person" view.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

needs help in life in different areas. But more of the whole they cant do

comments.author: Plague Doc

comments.text:
+TheAllstar22 I see. Your definition of "strong minded" is what I would 
call "healthy minded". Personally to me "strong minded" can cause bad and 
good things to happen. To me "strong minded" is more of a "stubborn, take 
every measure possible, willing to suffer for the goal" kind of thing.
People with eating disorders know that what they are doing is wrong and 
harmful most if not all of the time.
Many get better without help, many want to recover and ask for help of 
their own free will.
There are many that die because "it" is stronger than them, IMO those are 
the weakminded ones.
I agree that a person under your definition of strong minded will either 
not get into bad stuff in the first place or when they do find themselves 
there get out of it by themselves.
If you also mean to say that a person who suffers from an eating disorder 
and who seeks professional help is weakminded I would definitely not agree 
with that.
No man is an island. Asking for advice/help is sometimes a strong thing to 
do.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

comments.text:
+Yvonne de Rooij You dont seem to understand what I meant by weak minded. A 
weak minded person to me is someone who is  unable to realise that they're 
messing up their life and make a change. Is it difficult to change your 
life? hell yes. But a strong minded person would for one, not have themself 
in that position and two, they'd be able to spot the problem and make a 
change. I used to be a weak minded person in my late teens as I developed a 
drug issue later on, I noticed that it was making my life go down hill and 
changed it in an instant. Went clean without asking anyone for help or 
going to a therapist. It's all about commitment, if you want to change and 
commit to it, you will change. Weakminded people tend to need that guiding 
hand or someone to inform them on what to do or what can help.
comments.author: Plague Doc

comments.text:
+Barcroft TV I disagree, you can try to hide something but if you feel as 
something is wrong you can spot it out quite easily. For example if you 
make dinner and your child only eats a tiny amount she's not leaving the 
table until the plate is clean. If I have to force feed my child I would do 
so.
comments.author: Plague Doc

comments.text:
Most real anorexics aren't attention seekers at all, Most of them cover up 
their bodies in baggy clothes and are generally secretive.
For most of them it isn't about being attractive or getting more attractive 
by losing weight.
For most (if not all) of them it's about being in control and getting to 
weight loss goals can be addictive.
When they get to a goal weight they decide to continue on to a new lower 
goal weight and it can go on and on.
Usually anorexia is a coping mechanism, a way to feel in control when other 
things in your life are out of your control.
I find it funny how a lot of men, who don't know about eating disorders, 
think a chick "go's anorexic" in order to attract them.
Not everything females do that impacts their appearance is even about the 
opposite sex.
I understand they would make that assumption when you look at modern media 
though.
Almost none of anorexics are weak minded. Even though they have a mental 
disorder most anorexics are the strongest minded people you will ever meet. 
To go against a basic need like food requires a strong person.
It would be better if they turned this strong will towards healthy living 
and healthy weight maintenance but most anorexics are definitely not weak 
minded.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

comments.text:
+TheAllstar22 Perhaps if better support was available to all young people, 
fewer disorders of this kind would occur, but once people have developed 
eating issues they don't always realise how unwell they are, so don't 
believe they need to seek therapy - nor may such help be easy for them to 
find, although we agree that therapy is a good idea. It's an extremely 
regrettable situation. We appreciate your point of view about you'd handle 
things as a parent - however, anorexics sometimes become shockingly good at 
hiding their condition from their families. Parents can struggle to know 
how to approach the problem too.

captions.text: START

00:01
AIMEE: I'm achieving things, and I want other

anorexics to see that they can achieve things
as well because it's such a trait with the

illness that you don't have any belief
in yourself.

00:12
COMM: Like so many teenagers Aimee Corner
was desperate to fit in.

00:17
AIMEE: I used to look at all the popular girls

and they used to be like quite thin and I
thought if I'm thin then maybe people will
start liking me.

00:26
COMM: And this belief led her to starve herself
until she was dangerously underweight.

00:31
AIMEE: I always wanted to get down to four

and a half stone, and that was like my goal
weight. I think realistically I knew I would

never get to it because I probably would have
died.

00:43
COMM: Aimee, from Washington, Tyne and Wear

admits she was just eight years old when her
problems with foods began.

00:49
AIMEE: I just remember like as tory being

told by my dad and it was about someone who
knew that his friend had choked on a piece

of meat and I thought I better stop eating
my food fast and it got to the stage where
I was frightened to eat any solid foods,

01:10
COMM: And by the age of 14, her difficulties

had escalated as she faced bullying, and
desperately wanted to be liked at school.

01:17
AIMEE: I thought people would start to like

me more if I lost weight because I thought
I would change into a different person. I

just thought I'll just keep losing weight,
I don't care, I just don't care about eating
any more and I got down to literally thinking I could survive off like a spoonful of
yoghurt and two forkfuls of potato.

01:35
MAUREEN: We knew she was losing weight

but we didn't think it was that. We didn't
realise it was anorexia.

01:41
COMM: As well as starving herself Aimee was

also exercising compulsively to increase her
weight loss.

01:48
AIMEE: As I got more and more unwell, like

I couldn't like do proper exercise, so I used
to walk everywhere but then it gradually built

up, I mean some mornings I wasn't even going
to sixth form because I would spend the entire
morning walking around like, the local area.

02:03
AIMEE: Then I would walk to sixth form for

like two hours in the afternoon, then I would
walk home, and then I would try and get out

again to walk even more. At most I would say
I was doing like 6 to 8 hours of walking a
day.

02:16
COMM: Eventually her obsession saw her stop
eating and drinking for two whole weeks.

02:21
AIMEE: I thought if I didn't eat at all then

my weight loss would continue rapidly and
I thought I'm sorted.

02:27
AIMEE: But then obviously they caught me in
time to put me in the hospital.

02:31
COMM: Being hospitalised was the wake up call
she needed.

02:34
AIMEE: I remember sitting in the ambulance

on the way to the hospital and the paramedic
was like I don't actually know how you're

still conscious or how you're actually still
alive because someone with a blood sugar this
low should be a coma, they should be dead.

02:48
AIMEE: It's horrible when I look, I don't

look like me, I look like an old woman. Like
it just ages you so much, I look like seventy

on some of them photos and I used to think
I looked nice.

03:01
DIANE: I was in hospital with her and obviously

I had to wash her and I know it sounds awful
but can't - I couldn't bear to like touch

her, when you washed her you could
feel everything, like her shoulder, collar

bones, her spine and her hair was coming out
in clumps, it just broke my heart.

03:23
COMM: Now nineteen, Aimee is trying to increase
her weight to a healthy eight stone, two.

03:29
AIMEE: But it wasn't until I hit my lowest

weight and then something clicked in my head
and I actually can't live like this. I thought

I've had like five years of this, I just can't
deal with it any longer so I started eating

and eventually I put on like a bit of weight
and they discharged me, I'm eating better

than I've ever ate in about five years, COMM: And
she's about to start a degree in Psychology.

03:54
AIMEE: I want to be able to help other anorexics

because it makes me feel awful seeing how
much they suffer and I've conquered some

of my fears and I want to show them from a
recovered anorexic's point of view that you
can do it.

title: Teen Anorexia Survivor Wants To Help Others Battle Eating Disorders
